captions.text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

The Mercedes C63 Coupe has many
notable attributes, not

the least of which is the fact
that its small, two-door body,

which normally runs a 2.2 liter
diesel motor, has a 480
horsepower 6.2 liter V8.

That's 66 horsepower
more than a BMW M3.

But perhaps the C63's best
boast is the relationship

between that V8 and
its rear tires.

You see, the C63 behind me has
the Power Pack fitted, which

gives it 480 horsepower, 368
foot pounds of torque.
They're big numbers.

But the rear tire is just
255 in section.

That to me gives it
an unprecedented
amount of power to rubber.

Let's think of it as a power
to rubber ratio.
It's the biggest in its class.

In fact, outside of stuff like
the 1,099 horsepower

Koenigsegg Agera R, I can't
think of a car that is better

qualified to destroy
its rear tires.

So this is a C63 on absolutely
standard tires, 18-inch rims.

The rear tires are 255 sections,
the fronts are 235s.

I've left the systems
on now, OK?

I'm getting oversteer
everywhere.

This is a Millbrooks
handling track.

It's quite famous actually
because it's treacherous.

[INAUDIBLE], and there's
not massive amounts.

We have a concrete surface,
which is quite
harsh on the tires.

So you can see, I've having
to make very few steering
corrections.
[INAUDIBLE], I have to say.
But you know what?

In these conditions, this
doesn't feel like it has an
enormous amount of grip.

When we say, "mechanical grip,"
we mean, "tire grip,"

because there is no aero
grip in this car.

Doesn't feel that grippy,
because the
surface is a bit wet.

What the hell is it going to
be like when I've got a 125
section tire on it?
The mind boggles.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

That's right, we're going to
alter the power to rubber

ratio even further in
favor of that motor.

These are space-saver tires that
are supposed to be used

to get you to the next garage
after a puncture.

In fact, these are special AMG
versions that have vast spokes

to clear those massive
brake calipers.

And so here we are, the change
from 255 to 125.

Looks kind of slippy,
doesn't it?

Now there are two ways of
looking at the choice little
modification behind me.

On the one hand, we could get
the calculators out, go all

geeky, and work out the
exact increase in
power to rubber ratio.

Or should that be decrease
in rubber to power ratio?
I can't work it out.

On the other hand, we could do
what my photographer, Neil,

just said to me earlier, well,
hang on a minute, the 125

section space-saver's about a
third of the width of a normal

tire, a normal 255
section tire.

So that's about three times
the horsepower.

So let's say the car's got
around 1,200 horsepower.

So what we have behind me
is a C63 Coupe with 1200
horsepower.
And that is a good thing.

And so here we have it, this
is the C63 AMG Coupe with

Power Pack, 480 horsepower,
on 125 section tires.
What's it going to be like?

Got manual, gearbox selected,
I've got all the traction
control off.
It's a little tippy in here.
See what we get.

Tires are at 60 PSI, which
feels quite a lot.

So this is [INAUDIBLE]
throttle.

So there we go, oversteer
immediately.
Oh, oh, oh.
This is marvelous.

We have just invented possibly
the greatest driving machine
on the planet.

The C63 Coupe on space-savers
might be the best handling car
in the world.
Oh, come on.

This was in third gear last
time, and this time it's full
[INAUDIBLE].

I got no traction in third,
it just lights up.
[LAUGHS]

Can't quite ignore that
one, but all the rest
of it's just marvelous.

It's got a locking
deferential.

Non-standard, but you
need it for this.
Oh, come on.

This is the best handling
car I've driven in ages.
It just is so predictable.
It's just a joy.
It's a joy.
OK, initial impressions.

If you're going to buy a C63, it
needs to have space-savers.

This is the bit when we get to
discuss the moral of this

brief tale as you watch some
sexy, slo-mo shots at 200
frames per second.

A bit like they did at the
end of He-Man, but He
gets a great new V8.

So is there anything serious to
be learned from bunging an

AMG onto pathetically small
tires and pulling big drifts?

Actually, you know
what, there is.

Modern sports cars are now so
obsessed with lap times and

circuit performance, that at
normal road speeds they're

mostly boring because they never
come close to moving

around, making the
driver work.

OK, a 125 section's excessive,
but this does prove that
narrower tires equal fun.

And on the street, fun
is better than speed.
[CLASSICAL MUSIC PLAYING]

title: The Mercedes C63 AMG Experiment - /CHRIS HARRIS ON CARS

comments.author: ITsIMP0RT4NT

comments.text:
Contact patch is what counts, not tyre cross section - the contact patch 
varies constantly, so depending on the tyre, pressure, the conditions, 
speed, braking, accelerating forces, weight transference etc, increasing 
the cross section by a few centimeters may have little effect on the 
average contact patch (so the 255 standard tyres are probably just fine and 
just upping to say a 275 might not make much difference to grip).

People often make the mistake of thinking that just slapping on some wider 
rubber will always improve all around grip.

Of course in this case the changes are drastic - no doubt compounded by the 
space savesr most likely having very basic tech in its components compared 
to the high tech Continentals that came off.﻿
comments.author: Matthew Sharpe

comments.text: +B. Bazza it depends on the terrain
comments.author: Riley Williams

comments.text:
+Jake Gilmour
what are you on about? a contact patch is just the rubber touching the 
ground. the guy was implying that width is the only thing that matters but, 
depending on tread type, a wider tyre can have less contact with the ground.
comments.author: B. Bazza

comments.author: iTheGeek

comments.text:
+noobtubeeeeeee​ no, similar contact patch area, different shape, wider and 
shorter. 
The advantage of wider tyres is the wider shape of the contact patch can 
result in a smaller slip angle due to lower contact patch deformation, 
leading to more grip, but this is also dependent on a load of other factors 
beyond just tyre width. It's complicated stuff, but in my experience a well 
designed quality narrower tyre will often perform much better than a wider 
cheaper tyre.

comments.text:
Chris, your/Neil's man maths is a bit out here - the C63 PP makes 487bhp. 
[487 / 125] x 255 = 993.48 - so you've created a 993 and a half horsepower 
C63, not a 1200hp one. Good fun though. It'd be great to see a virtuous 
circle of less rubber, less power, less braking power, less weight going on 
- even the MX5 has got big and soft compared to the original FFS...﻿

comments.author: Quentin Freeman

comments.text:
+Quentin Freeman Ok... I'm 52 years old, short sighted, and had a rather 
serious head injury a couple of years ago. Chances that I will ever fly 
anything again - let alone an Apache - are rather small. I am aware that 
the length and detail and complexity of the training to operate any 
sophisticated aircraft are hundreds of times more complex and comprehensive 
than to operate a road vehicle. This is obvious. We don't try to train road 
users to the same level of expertise and proficiency we try to give combat 
pilots, or pilots of sophisticated jet passenger or transport aircraft. The 
point I was trying to make, is that driving a car and operating an aircraft 
are fundamentally different, just as driving a car and riding a unicycle 
are different. All 3 require lots of your attention, but they require it in 
slightly different ways. The unicycle requires reflexes. The Apache 
requires mental skills. If your reflexes and multitasking were terrible, 
you probably shouldn't fly it, but mostly what you do in an aircraft is a 
mental game like chess, or algebra & statistics. What you do on a unicycle 
is more like trying to balance a pencil on the palm of your hand.
comments.author: Kneedragon1962

comments.text: +Quentin Freeman Cool

comments.author: Quentin Freeman

comments.text:
+Quentin Freeman Have I got yoke time? Yes. Have I solo'd? No.Have I got an 
active logbook? No. Have I got recent stick & rudder time? No.Do I love 
aeroplanes, before motorbikes or sportscars, girls or well matured single 
malt whiskey? LOL, you never quite grow out of this kind of little boy 
infatuation.
comments.author: Kneedragon1962

comments.text:
+Kneedragon1962 Have you really flown an aircraft before? It takes months, 
sometimes years to learn to properly pilot an aircraft. You can learn to 
drive a car or motorcycle in day, maybe a week for slow learners. You're 
also usually moving much faster on average, so mistakes can cost you far 
more quickly. The fastest car ever went 756, and the fastest aircraft went 
25,000. You've got much less time to react than you think, because the 
vehicle is more difficult to regain control of. Aircraft aren't as 
maneuverable as ground vehicles. And God forbids something happen in a car 
or on bike, you might live, but coming in from thousands of feet in the air 
moving at any speed out of control, you die. When you pilot an aircraft, 
you must get it right. If that isn't pressure I don't know what is.
comments.author: Quentin Freeman

comments.text:
+Quentin Freeman Really? About what? The complexity of flying an aircraft? 
LOL. I don't think you could surprise me much there. Ralph Mitchel, Kelly 
Johnson and Barnes Wallis were my heros as a kid, as I watched Neil 
Armstrong step off the ladder on live tv. I learned to read on Biggles, and 
the first adult book I read was Reach for the Sky, Paul Brickhill, in 1970. 
The first plane I got to fly was a 172 owned by the boy scouts, in '75. By 
that time I had moved on from designing control line models to 4 chan RC 
ones...
comments.author: Kneedragon1962

comments.text: +Kneedragon1962 You'd be suprised.
comments.author: Quentin Freeman

comments.text:
+Quentin Freeman Complicated... Depends. Yes, there's some complexity in 
operating an aircraft, but there's some complexity in driving through 
London or New York or Sydney too. There's some complexity in operating a 
motorbike. I rode them for 40 years and I still have an R6 race bike. 
Complexity is part of the problem, time constraints is another, task 
management and prioritisation is another. Being able to ignore you 
instincts and trust your instruments, is a huge one. Being able to 
correctly read and interpret those instruments, under pressure, is another. 
Aircraft can be hard, but you have generally got a few moments to think. A 
car or motorbike near the limit of performance & control, it has to be 
reflex. It does everything too quickly for you to think about, it has to be 
like standing on one leg - you have to just KNOW what to do. There can be 
situations like that in aircraft too, but you don't often get into them.
comments.author: Kneedragon1962

comments.text: +Fading Light Not really, flying an aircraft is very complicated
comments.author: Quentin Freeman

comments.text:
That's not quite true. In principle, everyone could learn to walk a small 
tightrope with training, or sing a song (competently) in front of an 
audience.  In practice, some people are just not cut out for that.
comments.author: Kneedragon1962

comments.text: +Kneedragon1962 Im pretty sure everyone can fly an aircraft with training.
comments.author: Fading Light

comments.text:
+Kneedragon1962 having so much confidence is bad and will risk a accident 
by a fuck ton if i were you do someting about it cause its the most 
dangerous thing you can have if you dont have the skill to back it up. my

comments.author: ED kratos

comments.text:
Well ... 'everyone' is a big call. Years ago I would have completely agreed 
with you, but then I took my teenage kids to the local hire-kart place to 
teach them opposite lock. My son, about 14, picked it up quickly and well. 
My daughter, going 16, was a rather dismal flop at it. Ten years on, and my 
son drives rather well. My daughter is overconfident and still doesn't have 
a good feel, but she 'knows' she can chuck a car around like a rally car. 
All it gave her was a redneck attitude. Her actual skill level is no better 
than normal, but her confidence is huge and misplaced.

Have I changed my opinion? Not exactly... Let's just say it isn't simple. 
Not everybody CAN be taught high performance driving, like not everybody 
can be taught to fly an aircraft well.
comments.author: Kneedragon1962

comments.text:
+Wee Woo Google adblock, very poipular and easy to find. It installs into 
your internet browser (chrome, firefox or internet explorer) and will 
remove banner ads/commercials from youtube (and other sites).

You can also install 'ghostery' so you dont get tracked by advertisers to 
have specific ads targeted at you.

And 'hola better internet' lets you watch US/Canadian/British netflix from 
anywhere in the world if you have a netflix account.

comments.author: Bigboomer

comments.text:
The theory is in terms of weight per square inch making a difference, but 
in actuallity it wouldn't work like that Re: grip levels. You'd overload 
the smaller tyre at a far lower speeds than the wider tyre. More weight on 
a tyre will give it more grip, but only up to a certain point. Beyond that 
point the tyre becomes over loaded and loses grip.

comments.text:
In a perfect world with no imperfections on the road surface, a 1" wide 
tire will have just as much grip as a 10" wide tire. This is due to the 
pounds per square inch on the road surface being much higher on the 1" over 
the greatly distributed forces on the 10 incher.
comments.author: Chris Ireland

comments.author: eddytrochez

comments.text:
Load does increase traction to a certain point but after that it only takes 
away. The wings are used for higher speeds where tires start to lift off 
the road. The downforce is used to keep the vehicle planted on the ground 
and handle better more than have less wheel spin at the start. Wings will 
actually decrease a vehicle's top speed (due to drag) but increase 
stability at speed. Handling does rely on more factors than just tire grip, 
however, the weight affects every one of those factors.
comments.author: Justin Clark

comments.text:
More surface area = less load. Less load = better traction to a certain 
point. Its really simple. Tire load sensitivity all takes that into 
account. And yet you wont accept it, because youre stupid and now you have 
talked so much bullshit, that you have to keep defending, else I would win. 
Stupid people who think they are smart. Very dangerous. Lets hope you dont 
have any power. Hell, lets hope you dont have a job that has anything to do 
with cars, because then I feel sorry for your customers.
comments.author: coolhund

comments.text:
Hahaha, a complete retard, thinks hes smart and tries to explain things 
that are completely irrelevant to the topic, just so he sounds smart. You 
said load is the same as downforce. But it isnt. Load happens in many 
different ways when braking, accelerating, in turns, etc, and downforce is 
only a part of it. I linked you the simple facts of tire load sensitivity, 
and yet you continue to argue about HARD FACTS and call me stupid. Very 
funny. Please continue to make an idiot out of yourself.
comments.author: coolhund

comments.text:
It's hard for me to explain physics and aerodynamic principles to someone 
who is probably still in middle school. "Down force" is pretty much a 
downwards pressure exerted by the wings to the main chassis. Air pushes 
DOWN on the wing! When something pushes, it is adding pressure to whatever 
it pushing against. and in this case, the pressure is known as down force. 
I know it's hard for you to wrap your head around this, but you'll get it 
once you get into high school and learn physics.
comments.author: BIGMUSCLE

comments.text: Downforce is air, load can be anything. So its not the same, fucking noob.
comments.author: coolhund

comments.text:
LOL Do you know what the term "downforce" means? Air pushes down on a race 
car wing, the wing pushes down on the chassis, and the chassis pushes down 
on the tires! THIS CREATES BETTER CONTACT WITH THE ROAD=MORE TRACTION! When 
you push on something, you are inserting some force or weight into that 
thing. The weight the air moving over wing generates is what's pushing down 
on the car. The car that flew at la mans did so because it didn't have 
enough down force pushing down on it!
comments.author: BIGMUSCLE

comments.text:
It's not my "logic", it's basic physics. Handling doesn't depend solely on 
grip, you have to consider suspension setup, chassis rigidity, center of 
gravity, etc. Heavy cars are slower around corners due to the fact that 
they are heavy, not because they don't have grip. and it doesn't matter how 
much grip a car has, if it doesn't have good power-to-weight ratio, it will 
be slower. You should know all this by now! How old are you, 10?
comments.author: BIGMUSCLE

comments.text:
So, following your "logic", extremely heavy cars would have better handling 
than light cars. Ok. Dream on, F&F kiddy.
comments.author: coolhund

comments.text:
Race cars have big wings to increase downforce, so with less load, the 
tires grip more and at very high speeds they dont take off. You surely know 
the very well known video of the le mans car that took off and crashed 
horribly because of not enough downforce. Or maybe not........ Downforce is 
not more load. Read the article and you will realize that it is not 
proportional on tires and has diminishing rates from certain points on. Its 
easy to read. But I guess you sub 50 IQ people are too stupid.
comments.author: coolhund

comments.text:
Again for you, since you also seem to be unable to read: 
Tire_load_sensitivity wiki article. Ive stated the simple facts, but simple 
physics seem to be too weak for huge egos like you guys have. Nothing more 
I can do, except laugh at your ignorance.
comments.author: coolhund

comments.text:
Wider tires aren't meant to "lessen the load..", wider tires have better 
traction due to the fact that they have more surface-area (contact) with 
the pavement. The wider the rubber, the more contact with the road you'll 
have... wish means more traction!!!! It has noting to do with "load" or 
whatever bullshit you are talking about. Even though you have no clue what 
you are talking about, you are still arrogant enough to scream them as if 
you do.
comments.author: BIGMUSCLE

comments.text:
More load=more grip. Why the fuck do you think race cars have huge wings in 
the back? They have wings in order to have down force, and down force is 
just a fancy word for more load.
comments.author: BIGMUSCLE
